Would you consider the fallback config?
@zhiics @vinx13 @anijain2305 Can you please review?
@tqchen Could you help review? Thanks!
Did we tune conv2d kernel on cuda? Even we ignore the nms and argsort overhead, tvm is still slower than mxnet+cudnn.

> Did we tune conv2d kernel on cuda? Even we ignore the nms and argsort overhead, tvm is still slower than mxnet+cudnn.

I don't think so. @Laurawly ?

> If we use verbose mode, we should get most performance improvement for inceptionv3?

Maybe. I did see the schedule AutoTVM found for some shapes (not in Inception V3) uses a combination of factors and power of two. However, the tuning space grows rapidly and it requires longer search time or smarter search algorithm.

@yidawang @kevinthesun No, we didn’t update the conv2d auto tvm log for maskrcnn. It’ll be interesting to see if we can outperform mxnet + cudnn after auto tune without nms and argsort. One way to alleviate the argsort slow performance is to use external state-of-the-art library cub’s argsort. Another way is to fall back nms to cpu. Also I wonder if concat decreases the performance as well.

@tqchen thanks for the ping, this PR has been a little dormant and requires some work, I'll place a WIP tag  on it. The main issue right now is to get a schedule template that matches NCHWc in terms of performance.
https://discuss.tvm.ai/t/rfc-vta-bfloat16-fp8-fp9-posit-tensor-core/4014

@icemelon9 @zhiics @jroesch @MarisaKirisame @kevinthesun @yongwww @srkreddy1238 Please take a look.

> @comaniac , the fallback config is already set. Here, we directly use the NCHW fallback config. This happens during the alter_op_layout conversion from conv2d to conv2d_nchwc_int8.
> Next week, I am going to a do a much larger sweep of ic and oc to check robustness. I can incrementally build then.

Make sense. Thanks for the clarification.

Thanks @jackwish I have update accordingly
@zhiics Please review.

Frankly, I don't think that this is something that needs to be discussed. Everything related to VTA uses version 2019.1 of Vivado. Only the bitstream generation script still uses version 2018.3. If you `grep` the TVM project for `2018.3` you only find this line:
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/9e4f07b4695a8849590cdd46de662e3fa273d59b/vta/hardware/xilinx/scripts/vivado.tcl#L19

This is an actionable issue IMHO, not something to troubleshoot. If you still disagree, I'm happy to open a thread in https://discuss.tvm.ai/

---

On the other hand, if you `grep` for `2019.1`, you find multiple occurrences in `docs/vta/install.md`, but nowhere else. 

If version `2018.3` should be used for VTA, I'd be happy to open a PR to change the documentation.

@tqchen @herbakamil I looked into the docker container, but found that there is no llvm-config-6.0 at all...

I can confirm that build succeeded when Dockerfile uses llvm-config-8 instead.
@vinx13 wait for your comment

Hmm, perhaps two take aways, we should fix the docker file, and ideally we should have nicer error messages when we cannot find llvm-config. @junrushao1994 can you help on that?
Thanks for looking into the problem!
I agree the lines can be blurred here :) we also use both the forums for general development discussions as well. Reopen the the issue for now to see if it is something we can fix, cc @tmoreau89

@flip1995 thanks for reporting the issue; the migration to 2019.1 is problematic indeed as you have found due to compilation issues in Vivado after generating the HLS kernels in 2019.1. Interstingly if the HLS kernels are generated with 2018.3 and later compiled with 2019.1 there won't be an error. This requires a fix, I would say let's keep the issue open for now so we can give it visibility. I'm traveling at the moment so won't be able to apply a fix right away. As a temporary fix I suggest compiling with 2018.3.
Thanks @anijain2305 @comaniac @kevinthesun
@jroesch Could you take one more look at this PR?
cc @jwfromm @tqchen, pretty minor addition to https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/3849.

The CI does not build docker images, we manually build docker images and upload them to the docker hub. This is something that we overlooked, we could try to add a nightly that rebuild docker images if necessary in the future.
I wonder if we should define the prelude function in text format for better readability. Not sure whether the text parser is powerful enough.
@tqchen I have resolved the CI issue. Can you have a check?

To me as the person who is testing tvm on our model the big surprise was that there was no ready docker image to test Android tuning tutorials. Because tutorials are very nice. Also I had to think a while which dockerfile is appropriate and finally I modified the one for demo_android because this one I guess id the most comprehensive. Anyway I will see if today I manage to run these tutorials.

BTW, as TVM might be sub-moduled by other frontend libraries, their compilation flags `USE_XXX` may conflict. What is the best practice here? Should we prefix those flags as `TVM_USE_XXX`? Thanks!

Also CC: @were

@jroesch @tmoreau89 
```
In file included from /root/tvm/vta/src/runtime.cc:29:0:
/root/tvm/vta/include/vta/hw_spec.h:104:33: error: 'VTA_LOG_UOP_BUFF_SIZE' was not declared in this scope
 #define VTA_LOG_UOP_BUFF_DEPTH (VTA_LOG_UOP_BUFF_SIZE - VTA_LOG_UOP_WIDTH + 3)
```

Can you explain where you declare in `VTA_LOG_UOP_BUFF_SIZE`
 in https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/vta/include/vta/hw_spec.h ?
@apivovarov I think `VTA_LOG_UOP_BUFF_SIZE` is a variable to be customized, and it's defined in [vta_config.json](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/vta/config/vta_config.json). Hope this helps.

@liangfu Can you reproduce the error? Try to build with LLVM
```
mkdir build
cd build
cp ../cmake/config.cmake .
cmake USE_LLVM=ON ..
make
```
Install TVM from Source https://docs.tvm.ai/install/from_source.html

I am a bit confused by the semantics, how does this work? for example imagine that I have two any dimensions which will be (say 20, and 15 at runtime) it doesn't make sense to broad cast against non-1 dimensions.

I've been using the NHWC schedule written by @cowanmeg, which can be found in the quantized_end2end branch of her TVM fork (https://github.com/cowanmeg/tvm/tree/quantized_end2end). Maybe she can chime in on what works well for NHWC.
close for now. need more consideration about the auto_broadcast binding.
I see because you don't actual know the sign of `result_` at that time.
@wweic @icemelon9 I had addressed the review comment, can you guys give another round of review or approve?
@vinx13 how can I do that? I am not really familiar with tvm low level internal.

We are hitting exactly this problem: https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/f3abb3d88f3a1145a4454649b454fe0139f19bc9/src/arithmetic/bound_deducer.cc#L175

https://gist.github.com/yinghai/b51d4c6322fe6406dd1f3ab54b6905b0 is an alternative fix in the same spirit of this PR. In general I'm not sure how to fix this in the user side (loop_partition.cc).

Thanks for the PR, I will take a look this week. As a side note, I am pushing change to enable codegen for floordiv directly, which might simplify the logic of this PR, will send note if i manage to get something in this week.
@MarisaKirisame I will take a look
Thanks for the note, I just updated the image, please try again.

> I've been using the NHWC schedule written by @cowanmeg, which can be found in the quantized_end2end branch of her TVM fork (https://github.com/cowanmeg/tvm/tree/quantized_end2end). Maybe she can chime in on what works well for NHWC.

Thank you @jwfromm. I have taken a look at [the code](https://github.com/cowanmeg/tvm/blob/quantized_end2end//topi/python/topi/arm_cpu/conv2d.py#L369) (wish not using a wrong one), which is very similar to this PR. Still, I am very curious about the 5X performance, would you please share the detail of getting the performance (I will try @cowanmeg 's schedule too)? As mobilenet1 with NCHW can get 121 ms on Raspberry Pi 3B ([TVM benchmark page](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/wiki/Benchmark#results)), 5X means ~25 ms, which outperforms many *fast* quantization optimization approaches I think.
@MarisaKirisame I guess this is caused by the use of reference. It makes fusion and scheduling difficult. But I didn't reproduce the error on master, can you try rebasing?
Thanks @anijain2305

@tqchen  Please let me know your thoughts, this can be fixed with a check for the sign.
